summary: You can now visit the sets of ‘Game of Thrones’. Here’s how
title: You can now visit the sets of ‘Game of Thrones’. Here’s how
body:
You can now visit the sets of ‘Game of Thrones’. Here’s how

In what could be termed as good news for Game of Thrones fans, you can now visit the sets of your beloved fantasy-drama series. Excited?

According to a new announcement from the network, HBO is commemorating a decade of filming in Northern Ireland by opening up sites featured in the show to the public as attractions including Winterfell, Castle Black, and Kings Landing. In addition to the sets,…

View On WordPress

summary: Richard Madden in the new biopic film "Rocketman" his role as Elton’s manager John Reid for the first time and Taron Egerton as...
body:
Richard Madden in the new biopic film “Rocketman” his role as Elton’s manager John Reid for the first time and Taron Egerton as Elton John.

Reid worked with the singer for 30 years and was his lover for five – but the relationship ended in a bitter court battle over Elton’s finances.

reblog.comment:

Reid worked with the singer for 30 years and was his lover for five – but the relationship ended in a bitter court battle over Elton’s finances.

summary: “He’s not like the others. He never makes a sound. That’s why I named him Ghost. That, and because he’s white. The others are...
caption:
“He’s not like the others. He never makes a sound. That’s why I named him Ghost. That, and because he’s white. The others are all dark, grey or black.”


I love how different is Ghost between his siblings and he is white. Like snow and Like Dany 


And I love ho Black is Drogon like color which Jon choise to wear on the wall. and his eyes is  red like Ghost .


when Dany last time  entered the Drogos camp she loked  white wolf there. 

when Dany walked in Dothraki sea she heared Wolfs screaming


when Jon needed army but he thought about dragons, three dragon

When Maester Aemon spoke about dany and immediately Jon entered the room. and he repeated  what Aemon said about Dany

summary: So in the GoT tv series Jon probably ends up with either his half-sister or his cousin (which he grew up with like a half sister...
body:
So in the GoT tv series Jon probably ends up with either his half-sister or his cousin (which he grew up with like a half sister all those years). Does it bother anyone that both situations are bloodrelated? like… close blood related… 

Even though I like the idea of Jon & Sansa ending up together as characters (because I’m a Dany & Drogo fan till the end), I can’t completely wrap my mind around the fact that its incest in a way. idk… might just be me.

blog.name: laangdons
blog.title: Accidentally Adopted the Antichrist
blog.description: Duke | 30 | Student | Bi | Any pronouns | 98% of my problems are caused by fictional characters. VampChron, AHS, GoT, Pokemon. All my faves are problematic. Too old for discourse, don't even start. (Occasionally NSFW, but it will be tagged.) On Twitter @laangdons.

tags: (i don't want any angry people bitching that I didn't properly tag this)
answer:
I feel like you’re supposed to give a fandom, and I just… answer all of them. :’( But I’ll do it for GOT because. Well, that’s just what this blog is these days.

Do you have a NoTP in your fandom? Are they a popular OTP?: I guess Jonsa and Jonerys? I’m just not really into those.
Has fandom ever ruined a pairing for you?: Jonerys, I think. But that has more to do with (from what I’ve seen) a lack of critical thinking regarding Dany and… everything. My first watch-through, I was pretty into Dany’s character and then I…. wasn’t.
Most disliked character(s)? Why?: Melisandre and Stannis, for literal child murder. Dany, because of her massive hypocrisy.
Popular character you hate?: I don’t really know what fandom’s overall opinion on the Starks is, but I’m just not a huge fan of Catelyn and Robb. Catelyn’s a bitch and Robb is just boring.
Unpopular character you love? Sandor Clegane. I like how he accidentally found himself in the middle of a redemption arc. :’( And also Tormund is just… I have no idea how I wound up so heavily invested in that red-bearded weirdo, but here we are.

Naomi | She/Her | 24 | 🌞♉️| 🌜♑️| INFP | Hobbyist & Freelancer | Movie-Buff | Loves Critical Role, DnD, Tolkien, Game of Thrones| Gryffindor| TARGARYEN LOYALIST| This is my art blog! Sometimes I post original drawings, but this is all mostly fanart.
Please do NOT use, repost/copy/reproduce/trace, color, edit, publish, or distribute my art!

summary: For the first day of Rhaegar and Lyanna: AU week I am finally able to share these two commissioned pieces that I’ve been working...
caption:
For the first day of Rhaegar and Lyanna: AU week I am finally able to share these two commissioned pieces that I’ve been working on, that I was so happy to create! 

This is fanart of the main characters of the fanfic “The Lost Emperor” on Ao3! (I have not read the fanfic, but the contents seem interesting and I may read it in the future sometime!) Descriptions are in the image captions.

Watch the speedpaint here! 

Here’s my Commission Info!

summary:
This goes without saying; this analysis-rant has SPOILERS to the show (mostly), etc. You have been warned.
Disclaimer: these are...
body:
Cersei Lannister (part 1?)

This goes without saying; this analysis-rant has SPOILERS to the show (mostly), etc. You have been warned.

Disclaimer: these are my personal views, and I’m just expressing it here.

I am among the group of people that are currently in withdrawal after the season 7 finale of Game of Thrones. Nothing can fill that void except rewatching episodes, clips, and reading about the characters. I wanted to focus on one character in this rant; Cersei Lannister. Why her?

Cersei Lannister has been a central figure since season 1. She’s outlasted the notorious curse of main characters “dying like flies”. At lot can be said about her character, since she’s been around for so long. I’ve got a couple topics in mind; here is one of them:

How well does Cersei really know the Game of the Thrones?

In season 1, Cersei warned (poor) Eddard Stark that “when you play the Game of Thrones, you win or you die. There is no middle ground.”, after he reveals that he’s aware of her incestuous relationship with Jaime. Cersei quickly showed viewers that his values did not mean anything when having some kind of power. After Robert’s death, she tore up Ned’s letter stating him to be the Protector of the Realm, because she knew no one was coming to his aid. She knew he was too trusting, and she knew there was no one to stop her from diminishing the importance of honour (or decrees for that matter). Say what you will about Robert Baratheon; he kept Cersei in check (to an extent). Once he was gone, Cersei dived right into the game. 

A core aspect of her character is that she never thinks long term. She tends to consider after-the-fact, but never in the instances where it really matters. This is first seen when she fails to stop Joffrey from having Ned beheaded. We wouldn’t have a plot if this didn’t happen, but this is the example.

From what I know, Cersei has tricked herself into thinking that she knows exactly how the game works; however, I believe she knew very little in comparison to Margaery, Olenna, and her father Tywin. Cersei knew how it worked but in a very limited way. 

Her not thinking long-term is mostly the reason for this, and this only gets worse as the series progresses. She quickly lost control of Joffrey, unable to manipulate him. Tywin had always been the King of Westeros in everything but name, while she was trying to achieve some similar form of power. If she had found a way to keep Joffrey in check (instead of encouraging his sadism and self-centred mindset), you could say that she knew the game. 

It sounds contradictory, but I think she both knows the game, and also doesn’t know the game. She’s made it this far, which is an obvious example that she knows what she’s doing. However, she lost a lot to get here, which contributes to her failure to think long-term. She was fairly inactive during Joffrey’s rule (since she really couldn’t do anything); I’m talking about the Tyrells.

The Tyrells, specifically the women, were [in my eyes] the only players in the game that really knew what they were doing. Cersei was extremely vindictive of them, because she knew they knew what they were doing [Margaery and Olenna]. They were everything she was not and wanted to be .. Cersei’s character was a poor imitation of their characters. She did not have the knowledge of political intrigue that she wished she had, but Cersei does not try to compensate for this. That is another reason she does not have the game figured out. She would pretend to understand diplomacy, but slowly stopped caring for it. Getting Loras and Margaery imprisoned could have been considered her finding ways to work the game to her advantage (Tyrion’s trial is another example), but this would not aid her in the long term. Up until this point, the Tyrells were the most valuable allies to the throne, and even if Cersei wanted some kind of power (that would’ve resembled her father’s), she needed allies. Playing the game of thrones is, at the end of the day, more than just winning and dying. That’s something Margaery and Olenna knew and she did not. 

**on a side note, Cersei never truly defeated Olenna or Margaery in the game; Margaery died knowing why Cersei was not showing up, and thus did not let Cersei get the best of her, even until her last breath. Her dying can be equated to her ‘losing’, but I don’t think that’s the case, when the tension between them was marked by their skills in court. Olenna died dropping the mic like there was no tomorrow, since Cersei wholeheartedly believed Tyrion killed Joffrey until Jaime corrects her once he also learns the truth. Cersei never beat the women who knew the game like the back of their hands.**

Season 6 Cersei was bad, but Season 7 Cersei is even worse. Her close-minded view has prevented her from seeing something very basic; what she needs to do to live. Jaime voices this well, but Cersei believes she holds the power and can win despite it being clear that she cannot survive without allies. 

IN CONCLUSION: I wrote a bunch of random crap, but I think earlier seasons Cersei knew a little; now, Cersei has erased this part of her .. Cersei does not truly know the game anymore, having lost it once she installed the Faith Militant; that’s when playing the game became irrelevant to her, and that’s when she fated herself to lose this game. She’s made it this far, but she isn’t going to make it any farther. 

This is the first of many rants/analyses I’ll be writing; stay tuned for more!

Up until this point, the Tyrells were the most valuable allies to the throne, and even if Cersei wanted some kind of power (that would’ve resembled her father’s), she needed allies. Playing the game of thrones is, at the end of the day, more than just winning and dying. That’s something Margaery and Olenna knew and she did not. 

**on a side note, Cersei never truly defeated Olenna or Margaery in the game; Margaery died knowing why Cersei was not showing up, and thus did not let Cersei get the best of her, even until her last breath. Her dying can be equated to her ‘losing’, but I don’t think that’s the case, when the tension between them was marked by their skills in court. Olenna died dropping the mic like there was no tomorrow, since Cersei wholeheartedly believed Tyrion killed Joffrey until Jaime corrects her once he also learns the truth. Cersei never beat the women who knew the game like the back of their hands.**

Season 6 Cersei was bad, but Season 7 Cersei is even worse. Her close-minded view has prevented her from seeing something very basic; what she needs to do to live. Jaime voices this well, but Cersei believes she holds the power and can win despite it being clear that she cannot survive without allies. 

IN CONCLUSION: I wrote a bunch of random crap, but I think earlier seasons Cersei knew a little; now, Cersei has erased this part of her .. Cersei does not truly know the game anymore, having lost it once she installed the Faith Militant; that’s when playing the game became irrelevant to her, and that’s when she fated herself to lose this game. She’s made it this far, but she isn’t going to make it any farther. 

This is the first of many rants/analyses I’ll be writing; stay tuned for more!

trail.content_raw:
Cersei Lannister (part 1?)

This goes without saying; this analysis-rant has SPOILERS to the show (mostly), etc. You have been warned.

Disclaimer: these are my personal views, and I’m just expressing it here.

I am among the group of people that are currently in withdrawal after the season 7 finale of Game of Thrones. Nothing can fill that void except rewatching episodes, clips, and reading about the characters. I wanted to focus on one character in this rant; Cersei Lannister. Why her?

Cersei Lannister has been a central figure since season 1. She’s outlasted the notorious curse of main characters “dying like flies”. At lot can be said about her character, since she’s been around for so long. I’ve got a couple topics in mind; here is one of them:

How well does Cersei really know the Game of the Thrones?

In season 1, Cersei warned (poor) Eddard Stark that “when you play the Game of Thrones, you win or you die. There is no middle ground.”, after he reveals that he’s aware of her incestuous relationship with Jaime. Cersei quickly showed viewers that his values did not mean anything when having some kind of power. After Robert’s death, she tore up Ned’s letter stating him to be the Protector of the Realm, because she knew no one was coming to his aid. She knew he was too trusting, and she knew there was no one to stop her from diminishing the importance of honour (or decrees for that matter). Say what you will about Robert Baratheon; he kept Cersei in check (to an extent). Once he was gone, Cersei dived right into the game. 

A core aspect of her character is that she never thinks long term. She tends to consider after-the-fact, but never in the instances where it really matters. This is first seen when she fails to stop Joffrey from having Ned beheaded. We wouldn’t have a plot if this didn’t happen, but this is the example.

From what I know, Cersei has tricked herself into thinking that she knows exactly how the game works; however, I believe she knew very little in comparison to Margaery, Olenna, and her father Tywin. Cersei knew how it worked but in a very limited way. 

Her not thinking long-term is mostly the reason for this, and this only gets worse as the series progresses. She quickly lost control of Joffrey, unable to manipulate him. Tywin had always been the King of Westeros in everything but name, while she was trying to achieve some similar form of power. If she had found a way to keep Joffrey in check (instead of encouraging his sadism and self-centred mindset), you could say that she knew the game. 

It sounds contradictory, but I think she both knows the game, and also doesn’t know the game. She’s made it this far, which is an obvious example that she knows what she’s doing. However, she lost a lot to get here, which contributes to her failure to think long-term. She was fairly inactive during Joffrey’s rule (since she really couldn’t do anything); I’m talking about the Tyrells.

The Tyrells, specifically the women, were [in my eyes] the only players in the game that really knew what they were doing. Cersei was extremely vindictive of them, because she knew they knew what they were doing [Margaery and Olenna]. They were everything she was not and wanted to be .. Cersei’s character was a poor imitation of their characters. She did not have the knowledge of political intrigue that she wished she had, but Cersei does not try to compensate for this. That is another reason she does not have the game figured out. She would pretend to understand diplomacy, but slowly stopped caring for it. Getting Loras and Margaery imprisoned could have been considered her finding ways to work the game to her advantage (Tyrion’s trial is another example), but this would not aid her in the long term. Up until this point, the Tyrells were the most valuable allies to the throne, and even if Cersei wanted some kind of power (that would’ve resembled her father’s), she needed allies. Playing the game of thrones is, at the end of the day, more than just winning and dying. That’s something Margaery and Olenna knew and she did not. 

**on a side note, Cersei never truly defeated Olenna or Margaery in the game; Margaery died knowing why Cersei was not showing up, and thus did not let Cersei get the best of her, even until her last breath. Her dying can be equated to her ‘losing’, but I don’t think that’s the case, when the tension between them was marked by their skills in court. Olenna died dropping the mic like there was no tomorrow, since Cersei wholeheartedly believed Tyrion killed Joffrey until Jaime corrects her once he also learns the truth. Cersei never beat the women who knew the game like the back of their hands.**

Season 6 Cersei was bad, but Season 7 Cersei is even worse. Her close-minded view has prevented her from seeing something very basic; what she needs to do to live. Jaime voices this well, but Cersei believes she holds the power and can win despite it being clear that she cannot survive without allies. 

IN CONCLUSION: I wrote a bunch of random crap, but I think earlier seasons Cersei knew a little; now, Cersei has erased this part of her .. Cersei does not truly know the game anymore, having lost it once she installed the Faith Militant; that’s when playing the game became irrelevant to her, and that’s when she fated herself to lose this game. She’s made it this far, but she isn’t going to make it any farther. 

This is the first of many rants/analyses I’ll be writing; stay tuned for more!

title: [SPOILERS] Dany's Hair
body:
I’ve noticed that the number of braids in Dany’s hair steadily increase throughout the course of the series, along with the length of her hair. Is this because she is undefeated as Khaleesi? I remember in A Game of Thrones it was mentioned that an undefeated Khal never cuts his hair.



Source: https://ift.tt/2NUbNlq
